overview.title: Understanding Seborrheic Dermatitis
overview.intro: Welcome to the interactive database. This section offers an immediate visual summary of the main mechanism of pathology: the interaction between specific lipids and Malassezia. The key to remission lies in understanding fatty acid carbon chain lengths.

safe.label: Safe Alternative
safe.sub: Cannot be metabolized by the fungus. 100% Safe.

prevalence.label: Malassezia Prevalence
prevalence.sub: The problem isn't presence, but proliferation.

chart.title: The Science of Carbon Chains
chart.subtitle: This chart illustrates which oils and fatty acids feed Malassezia based on their molecular structure.

mechanisms.title: Pathological Mechanisms
mechanisms.intro: This section analyzes why Seborrheic Dermatitis occurs. It is not just "dry skin"; it is a complex inflammatory interaction. The charts show how specific fatty acids trigger a cytokine storm.

chart_inflammation.title: Inflammatory Response to Oleic Acid
chart_inflammation.interpretation_text: Oleic Acid (common in olive oil and human sebum) causes a massive increase (300-400%) in inflammatory markers IL-6 and IL-8.

steps.title: Barrier Compromise
steps.desc: The skin barrier weakens, allowing penetration.

steps.title: Lipid Feeding
steps.desc: Malassezia consumes C12-C24 lipids (from sebum or cosmetics).

steps.title: Free Fatty Acid Release
steps.desc: The fungus releases irritating unsaturated fatty acids on the skin.

protocol.title: Protocol and Implementation

faq.q: Is there a definitive cure for Seborrheic Dermatitis?
faq.a: NO. SD is chronic but highly manageable. Many achieve remission for months or years with the correct protocol, but relapses are possible if trigger products are used.

faq.q: Can I use my normal shampoo if I also use an antifungal one?
faq.a: NO. Using a normal shampoo with oils (triggers) is like throwing gasoline on a fire while trying to put it out with the antifungal. You must eliminate triggers.
NO. Only C12-C24 fatty acids. MCT Oil (C8/C10), mineral oil, and squalane are safe.

faq.q: If I am in remission, can I use an 'unsafe' product once?
faq.a: NOT RECOMMENDED. A single exposure to high-risk products (e.g., coconut oil mask) can reactivate a flare that lasts for weeks.

myths.title: It's just dry skin
myths.content: No, it's an inflammation caused by fungi. Adding traditional oils (Olive, Coconut) worsens the situation almost instantly.

myths.title: Coconut oil is antifungal
myths.content: In a test tube yes (lauric acid), but on skin lauric acid (C12) is the main explosive food for Malassezia.

myths.title: Organic products are safe
myths.content: Malassezia is natural! It loves nature. Many plant extracts and organic oils are its favorite food.
